Award.AwardTitle: Scalable Laser Printing of Three-Dimensional Living Tissue Constructs

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The rising success rate of transplants has resulted in a critical need for more tissues and organs. Approximately 95,000 people are on the waiting list for new organs in the US alone, and some die every day waiting for transplants. Organ printing provides a promising solution to the problem of organ donor shortage. This award supports fundamental research to generate knowledge that enables the scale up of a jet-based, orifice-free laser bioprinting technique for organ printing. Results from this research will enable the wider use of laser printing for the fabrication of living tissue constructs for implantation. In addition, this award will promote the development of bioprinting technologies for cell and organ printing and provide three-dimensional engineered tissues for cell behavior and pharmacokinetics studies.

In this new laser bioprinting technique, an optical scanner will be incorporated into the laser beam delivery system to optically guide laser pulses to efficiently transfer bioinks of a ribbon instead of mechanically moving the ribbon. The objective of this research is to understand the effects of the interaction of laser pulses-induced adjacent fluid jets on the jettability and printability during optical scanner-enabled laser-induced forward transfer bioprinting. The jettability will be evaluated based on whether two adjacent well-defined jets can be formed during jet formation, and the printability will be assessed based on whether a well-defined line can be formed from well-defined jets. The formation of each laser-induced jet will be modeled using the existing homogenous nucleation-based phase explosion theory. The governing fluid continuity and Navier-Stokes equations for droplet formation under the jet interaction will be solved numerically using a finite element method with mixed interpolation for spatial discretization as well as an implicit finite difference method for time integration. In order to derive a reduced system of equations and boundary conditions containing the governing physics, a scale analysis of the governing equations and interfacial conditions will be performed. The scale analysis results will be used to validate the numerical simulation on the onset of instability (droplet formation) under the effects of two adjacent jets. The resulting knowledge of the interaction of adjacent jets will be used to predict the influences of printing conditions such as the scanning speed of optical scanner on the jettability and printability and further validated during the laser bioprinting of cellular tubes.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
Laser-induced forward transfer printing is the bottom-up additive manufacturing of native tissues or organs through the three-dimensional bioprinting of multiple cell types and other biomaterials at designated positions. Such a biofabrication approach provides a promising solution to the organ donor shortage. While some major challenges in organ printing are biological, the scale-up bioprinting to produce viable tissue constructs is the first step towards successful organ printing, and laser-induced forward transfer-based laser printing is one of the promising bioprinting technologies to realize robotic bioprinting.

 

The study has resulted in new knowledge of the laser printing protocol in terms of optimal printing conditions, the printing-induced cell injury, the effect of living cells on the bioink printability, and the effects of overlap of adjacent jets on the jet formation and material deposition when using an optical scanner. Compared with cell-free bioink printing, the transfer threshold of the cell-laden bioink is higher while the jet velocity, jet breakup length, and printed droplet size are lower, shorter, and smaller, respectively. The addition of living cells transforms the printing type from jet-impingement printing with multiple breakups to droplet-impingement printing. During the printing of cell-laden bioinks, two non-ideal jetting behaviors, non-straight jet with a non-straight trajectory and straight jet with a non-straight trajectory, are identified mainly due to the local nonuniformity and nonhomogeneity of cell-laden bioinks. When an optical scanner is utilized for scale-up printing, a 30% overlap is found to produce continuous lines without satellite droplets.

 

Specifically, it has been demonstrated that three-dimensional cellular tubes, including constructs with bifurcated overhang structures, can be adequately fabricated under optimal printing conditions. The post-printing cell viability values immediately after printing as well as after 24-hour incubation are above 60% for printed straight and Y-shaped fibroblast tubes. This represents the first successful freeform laser fabrication of three-dimensional cellular constructs, demonstrating laser printing as a versatile tool for three-dimensional bioprinting. In addition, four Ph.D. and three undergraduate students have been trained in the course of this research project, and the resulting knowledge has been disseminated as journal publication as well as integrated into offering a graduate-level advanced manufacturing course.


Last Modified: 11/26/2019
Modified by: Yong Huang
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Laser-induced forward transfer printing is the bottom-up additive manufacturing of native tissues or organs through the three-dimensional bioprinting of multiple cell types and other biomaterials at designated positions. Such a biofabrication approach provides a promising solution to the organ donor shortage. While some major challenges in organ printing are biological, the scale-up bioprinting to produce viable tissue constructs is the first step towards successful organ printing, and laser-induced forward transfer-based laser printing is one of the promising bioprinting technologies to realize robotic bioprinting. The study has resulted in new knowledge of the laser printing protocol in terms of optimal printing conditions, the printing-induced cell injury, the effect of living cells on the bioink printability, and the effects of overlap of adjacent jets on the jet formation and material deposition when using an optical scanner. Compared with cell-free bioink printing, the transfer threshold of the cell-laden bioink is higher while the jet velocity, jet breakup length, and printed droplet size are lower, shorter, and smaller, respectively. The addition of living cells transforms the printing type from jet-impingement printing with multiple breakups to droplet-impingement printing. During the printing of cell-laden bioinks, two non-ideal jetting behaviors, non-straight jet with a non-straight trajectory and straight jet with a non-straight trajectory, are identified mainly due to the local nonuniformity and nonhomogeneity of cell-laden bioinks. When an optical scanner is utilized for scale-up printing, a 30% overlap is found to produce continuous lines without satellite droplets. The post-printing cell viability values immediately after printing as well as after 24-hour incubation are above 60% for printed straight and Y-shaped fibroblast tubes. This represents the first successful freeform laser fabrication of three-dimensional cellular constructs, demonstrating laser printing as a versatile tool for three-dimensional bioprinting. In addition, four Ph.D. and three undergraduate students have been trained in the course of this research project, and the resulting knowledge has been disseminated as journal publication as well as integrated into offering a graduate-level advanced manufacturing course.
